fields: Trace Object through GI tract: (mouth to anus)
*Know the anatomy discussed in this lecture and be able to trace the anatomical path of a substance from the mouth to the anus
*Know the anatomy discussed in this lecture and be able to trace the anatomical path of a substance from the mouth to the anus.

Characteristics: {{c1::Villi}} & {{c1::Crypts}}
Location: {{c1::small intestine}}
Function: Both increase {{c1::Surface Area}} and helps {{c1::with absorption}}
Disease involvement: {{c1::Celiac}} disease ({{c1::block folds}})
 
Characteristics: {{c1::Folds}} & {{c1::Rugae}}
Location: {{c1::stomach}}
Function: allow for {{c1::expansion}}

*Describe the villi and crypts and predict how changes in structure would impact function

From book:
-Structural features called villi and microvilli increase the surface area of the small intestine, maximizing the exposure of nutrients to digestive enzymes and creating a large absorptive surface.
-The epithelial cells lining the intestinal crypts secrete fluid and electrolytes (compared with the cells lining the villi, which absorb fluid and electrolytes)

• Pharmacodynamics:
Study of what {{c1::drugs}} do to the {{c1::body}} ({{c1::MOA}})

Ex: {{c1::Toxicity}} (side effect) and {{c1::Efficacy}}

  • Pharmacokinetics
 What the {{c1::body}} does to the {{c1::drugs}} ({{c1::ADME}}).
1. {{c1::Absorption}}
2. {{c1::Distribution}}
3. {{c1::Metabolism}}
4. {{c1::Elimination}}
*Define the terms: bioavailability, first-pass effect, pharmacodynamics, pharmacokinetics (ADME), and therapeutic window.

Therapeutic Window:

={{c1::Minimal effective dose(MEC desired)}} - {{c1::minimal toxic dose(MEC adverse)}}

Bioavailability (F)  =

{{c1::(AUC)o}}     
{{c1::(AUC)iv }} (100%)
 
Area {{c1::under the curve}} ({{c1::AUC}}) is measured
{{c1::Plasma levels}} are plotted against {{c1::time}}
*Define the terms: bioavailability, first-pass effect, pharmacodynamics, pharmacokinetics (ADME), and therapeutic window.
